Description: Hemispherical bowl of very fine Nile silt coloured entirely black on one side of the exterior and black-topped brown on the other. The exterior has strong diagonal rippling made by deep combing, and has been finely burnished. The interior is entirely black and has been rippled vertically and well burnished along the walls, while the interior base was left untreated and decorated with point burnishing in the centre with a cross-hatched motif that resembles a fish.
Curator's comments: Illustrated as Brunton’s (1937) All Black AB17, however only one side of the bowl is wholly black, the other side is black-topped brown. The base is also brown. The bowl was found in an undisturbed grave before the hands of an old man with a beard. It was covered with sherds and contained grains identified as emmer(?) wheat. Skins had been spread over the body and the pot.
Bibliographic references: Brunton 1937 / Mostagedda and the Tasian Culture (p. 35, 50, 58, pl. 18.AB17)
